captions.text:
Oh, come on. Do we look
like the sort ofchaps who'd
creep into a camp at night,

steal into someone's tent,
anaesthetize them,
tissue-type them,

amputate a leg
and run awaywith it ?
Search the thicket.

Oh, leg !
You're looking
fora leg !

Actually, l think
there is one there
somewhere.

Somebody must have abandoned
it here, knowing you were
coming after it.

We stumbled across it,
actually. They'll be
miles away by now.

We'll have to take
all the blame.

Hello, good evening
and welcome to
The Middle ofthe film.

Hello, and welcome to
The Middle ofthe Film,

the moment where we take a break
to inviteyou, the audience,
tojoin us, the filmmakers,

We're going to showyou
a scene from another film...

and askyou to guess
where the fish is.

But ifyou thinkyou know,
don't keep it toyourselves.

l wonderwhere
that fish has gone.
You did love it so.

You looked after it
like a son.

And it went
wherever l did go.
ls it in the cupboard ?

Wouldn'tyou like to know ?
It was a lovely little fish.

And it went
wherever l did go.

[ Man In Audience ]
It's behind the sofa !

[ Man in Audience ]
Have you thought ofthe
drawers in the bureau ?
Shh !

And it went
wherever l
did go.

Oh ! Fishy, fishy,
fishy, fish.

Uh, fish, uh, fish,
uh, fishy, ohh !

Ohhh ! Fishy, fishy,
fishy, fish !

That went
wherever l
did go.

[Audience ]
Look up his trunk !
Yeah ! It's in his trousers !

That was terrific !
Great ! Yeah !
Best bit so far.

comments.text:
Actually, "Drill" as it is called in the Forces serves not to make troops 
more effective killers or dim-witted automatons who blindly follow orders, 
it serves to make the recruit change their mental responses from thinking 
"I" into thinking "We". It makes the individual respond as a Team -if you 
will - and this, can mean the difference between life and death in a combat 
situation. Believe it or not, our troops fight for themselves and each 
other in time of war, not for a cause or ideal or even a politician!﻿

called "sarge" wearing a staff sergeant insgnia then calls himself sergeant

comments.author: nightfox802

comments.text:
Yeah. In Commonwealth armies, Sergeant Major is an appointment, not a rank, 
so it's quite possible for a Staff Sergeant to be appointed to the role 
(although usually they're actually WOs, not NCOs).
comments.author: wkcia

comments.text:
As satirical as this clip is, I think its actually a decent representation 
of the armed forces!  For a long time, I aspired to be in the air force, 
and joined the air cadets. But as time went on, I had my fair share of shoe 
polishing, ironing and MARCHING UP AND DOWN THE SQUARE!!!, and eventually, 
I just kind of came to think, "What the fuck am I doing with my life?". I 
mean, I completely appreciate the need for an army, air force etc. and I 
have full praise for those who enlist. But honestly, why does there need to 
be so much bullshit in the armed forces? Why do we need to waste shit-loads 
of hours marching pointlessly up and down a square and ironing our uniform 
to be perfect by made up standards? Disciplining, they might argue. But 
surely there has to be better, less fricking futile ways to discipline 
enlistees? And I don't think there's any justification for rules like 
having to take your beret off indoors and when you eat, or for getting a 
bollocking just for having a stain on your shirt or a button undone. 
They're just rules for the sake of rules. As far as I'm aware, in order to 
have an effective military force, you just need fit, disciplined and 
reliable people who know what they're doing. The extra added narcissism, 
dehumanization and life-wasting drill is just beyond me.﻿
comments.author: LasergunExtreme

comments.text:
It's a classic brain-washing technique. Make people do repetitive, 
incredibly boring tasks and your thinking brain switches off making you a 
lot more open to hypnotic suggestion. Church services work in much the same 
way as does TV advertising.
comments.author: Christian Koncz

comments.text:
Hmmm...I guess, but it just seems an excrutiatingly futile way of doing it. 
The armed forces obviously require disciplined personnel, but I don't think 
marching accomplishes it. The discipline is probably just naturally within 
the guys themselves. I think this because I have done LOADS of marching 
during my time as a cadet, and it hasn't served to increase the discipline 
of anyone. Some people are just disciplined, others are not.
comments.author: Edred Whittingham

comments.text:
It's all for control mate. They need to be able to have full control over 
their troops so that they will do exactly what they say in times of war. So 
they keep telling you what to do over and over and over again so that your 
brain subconsciously forms a habit thinking "I do what they tell me to do 
without questioning". Otherwise troops would much more hesitant towards 
killing innocents or giving their life for a cause.
comments.author: SeriousPlastiek

comments.text:
+LasergunExtreme Well, you wrote it perfectly "The extra added narcissism, 
dehumanization and life-wasting drill is just beyond me"; and so is for a 
lot of people, but, not for some others (someone would say fortunately), so 
remember what is the basic need of an army: 'Defence'. And that Defence 
doesn't mean a silent elbow in the ribs of the oponent (basketball style), 
it means a person capable of killing another person, and for that, no 
developed country has an actual training camp, so, dehumanization is the 
best way to train a regular brain and make it prone to the killing. And for 
the discipline, well, it's all about control, all about following orders, 
so the soldier get used to obey.
